body: Hi Sergio! We are getting close here. Thanks very much for your effort. Besides the comments in line can you please explain what is the purpose of the pom.xml? Perhaps as a comment in the pom.xml itself. It is needed to integrate with Apache build/test processes but this is where my knowledge ends. It would be nice to have this comment for people to understand why it is needed especially since it is unusual for a Python package.

R: @davorbonaci @kennknowles 

Here is a strawman PR to introduce some microbenchmarks for pieces of the SDK potentially in the critical path. This focuses on the cost of calling processElement in a DoFn using the various mechanisms available.
@dhalperi, this is important process-wise and how we manage changes in the benchmarks.

@silviulica, the main purpuse of this PR is to help Beam to manage the entire source base with Maven. It's a detail I always like to care in multi-language projects, because it's very important for a proper overall management. The version issue is just a consequence of this integrated build.

In the end the approach I used it's not very intrusive: The python folks can just focus on the Python stuff; but the Maven guys will automatically run some tasks when they're building the whole project.

Please, let me know if you find useful the approach, to then continue polishing details.

Thanks for the feedback.

@aaltay, I think I know why the CI is not happy. If I manually run the test from Maven (which is the end relies on `tox` as it was:

```

mvn test
...
```

I noticed the command uses `--no-deps` as argument. I have to admit I have not much experience with `tox`, but I guess that's why later we get a `ImportError: No module named dill`...

@wikier - Definitely the approach is good. I just wanted to leave a record of why we are doing it.  It is most likely obvious for people using Maven often but was not obvious for me :-) Thanks again for doing it.
:+1: thanks for contributing this!
LGTM, merged
Thanks!
LGTM

Merged.

Please backport in spirit to Dataflow.

@wikier I have reproduced the error you are seeing. 

The problem is you are importing and calling apache_beam.\* packages before the completion of the setuptools.setup() call. That call is responsible for installing requirements (including dill). Anything prior to that call should be self contained should not depend on anything but whatever is available in a default Python installation.

I understand this creates a chicken and egg problem. I am not familiar with maven - python integrations. Do you know how other people approach this problem?

One option I can think of is to open and parse the xml file for the version string inside the setup.py without using lxml (e.g. a single string search for version). It may not be robust but it will address this problem.
LGTM, merged.

- rename to `DataflowUnboundedReadFromBoundedSource`?

Also,
- move the examples cleanup to a separate PR

Ping @kennknowles: I've updated this based on recent churn this and jenkins is now green. Let me know if it looks good and I'll do a final rebase.

Regarding 3, according to http://docs.oracle.com/javaee/1.4/api/javax/jms/ConnectionFactory.html, we can read:

```
It is expected that JMS providers will provide the tools an administrator needs to create and configure administered objects in a JNDI namespace. JMS provider implementations of administered objects should be both javax.jndi.Referenceable and java.io.Serializable so that they can be stored in all JNDI naming contexts. In addition, it is recommended that these implementations follow the JavaBeansTM design patterns.
```

So a `ConnectionFactory` implementation is `Serializable`.

Lucas, its easier for people to review your code if you don't squash your commits, this allows for an easy way to see the diff and comments that were made on earlier versions still make sense. If you label them with !fixup at the beginning then committers will squash those CLs for you when merging your pull request.

For further details please take a look at http://beam.incubator.apache.org/contribution-guide/

@nevillelyh yep, thanks. Unfortunately, Bigtable team made backwards-incompatible changes in this release so we'll upgrade to 0.9 separately.

I don't know if the changed example is useful anymore. Isn't this just `WordCount` that writes to BigQuery?

Namely, this is just an ETL pipeline that doesn't actually show anything interesting about the programming model that isn't already covered in `WordCount`

Do the benchmarks depend on package-private stuff? I'd prefer to avoid the split package, meaning that we would put this stuff somewhere under a new `benchmarks` namespace or some such rather than the namespaces from the core SDK.

Mostly looks good, just a couple of minor comments.

They did depend on package-private stuff, but I made it public and moved them into their own microbenchmarks package. I could conceive of wanting to use package-private stuff in the same way tests do, but we can always do so by adding a thin wrapper to expose methods to benchmarks.
